Has whiſper'd in your Sleep, the pleaſing News
Of my Return; and you believ'd it real!
Perhaps too, in your Dream, you us'd me kindly;
And my preventing Image, reap'd the Joys
You meant awake to me.

sp.speaker: Alcm.
sp.l: Some Melancholy Vapour, ſure, has ſeiz'd
Your Brain, Amphitryon, and diſturb'd your Senſe:
Or Yeſternight is not ſo long a time,
But you might yet remember; and not force▪
An honeſt Bluſh into my glowing Cheeks,
For that which lawful Marriage makes no Crime.

sp.speaker: Amph.
sp.l: I thank you for my Melancholy Vapour.

sp.speaker: Alc.
sp.l: 'Tis but a juſt requital for my Dream.

sp.speaker: Phaedra.
sp.p: I find my Maſter took too much of the Creature laſt night, and now is Angling for a Quarrel, that no more may be expected from him to Night, when he has no Aſſets.

div.stage: [In the mean time Amph. and Alch. walk by themſelves, and frown at each other as they meet.

sp.speaker: Amph.
sp.l: You dare not juſtifie it to my face.

sp.speaker: Alcm.
sp.l: Not what?

sp.speaker: Amph.
sp.l: That I return'd before this hour?

sp.speaker: Alcm.
sp.l: You dare not, ſure, deny you came laſt night,
And ſtaid till Break of Day?

sp.speaker: Amph.
sp.l: O Impudence!—Why Soſia!

sp.speaker: Soſia.
sp.p: Nay, I ſay nothing; for all things here, may go by Enchantment (as they did with me) for ought I know.

sp.speaker: Alcm.
sp.l: Speak, Phaedra; Was he here?

sp.speaker: Phaedra.
sp.p: You know, Madam, I am but a Chamber-maid; and by my place, I am to forget all that was done over-night in Love-Matters,—unleſs my Maſter pleaſe to rub up my Memory with another Diamond.

sp.speaker: Amph.
sp.l: Now in the name of all the Gods, Alcmena,
A little recollect your ſcatter'd Thoughts;
And weigh what you have ſaid.

sp.speaker: Alcm.
sp.l: I weigh'd it well, Amphitryon, e're I ſpoke:
And She, and Bromia, all the Slaves, and Servants,
Can witneſs they beheld you, when you came.
If other Proof were wanting, tell me how
I came to know your Fight, your Victory,
The Death of Pterelas, in ſingle Combat?
And, farther, from whoſe hands I had a Jewel:
The Spoyls of him you ſlew.

sp.speaker: Amph.
sp.l: This is amazing!
Have I already given you thoſe Diamonds,
The Preſent I reſerv'd?

sp.speaker: Alcm.
sp.l: 'Tis an odd Queſtion:
You ſee I wear 'em; Look.

sp.speaker: Amph.
sp.p: Now anſwer, Soſia.

sp.speaker: Soſia.
sp.p: Yes, now I can anſwer with a fafe Conſcience, as to that point, all the reſt may be Art Magick; but, as for the Diamonds, here they are, under ſafe cuſtody.

sp.speaker: Alcm.
sp.p: Then what are theſe upon my Arm?

sp.speaker: Soſia.
sp.p: Flints, or Pebbles, or ſome ſuch Trumpery of enchanted Stones.

sp.speaker: Phaedra.
sp.p: They ſay the proof of a true Diamond is to glitter in the dark; I think my Maſter had beſt take my Lady into ſome By-corner, and try whoſe Diamond will ſparkle beſt.

sp.speaker: Soſia.
sp.p: Yet now I think on't, Madam, did not a certain Friend of mine preſent 'em to you?

sp.speaker: Alcm.
sp.p: What Friend?

sp.speaker: Soſia.
sp.p: Why another Soſia; one that made himſelf Soſia in my deſpight, and alſo unſociated me.

sp.speaker: Amph.
sp.p: Sirrah, leave your nauſeous Nonſenſe: break open the Seal, and take out the Diamonds

sp.speaker: Soſia.
sp.p: More words than one to a Bargain, Sir; I thank you: That's no part of prudence for me to commit Burglary upon the Seals: Do you look firſt upon the Signet, and tell me in your Conſcience, whether the Seals be not as firm as when you clapt the Wax upon them.

sp.speaker: Amph.
sp.p: The Signature is firm.

sp.speaker: Soſia.
sp.p: Then take the Signature into your own cuſtody, and open it; for I will have nothing done at my proper peril.

sp.speaker: Amph.
sp.p: O Heav'ns! Here's nothing, but an empty ſpace; the Neſt where they were laid.

sp.speaker: Soſia.
sp.p: Then if the Birds are flown, the Fault's not mine; here has been fine conjuring work; or elſe the Jewel, knowing to whom it ſhou'd be given, took occaſion to ſteal out, by a natural inſtinct, and ty'd it ſelf upon that pretty Arm.

sp.speaker: Amph.
sp.p: Can this be poſſible!

sp.speaker: Soſia.
sp.p: Yes, very poſſible: You, my Lord Amphitryon, may have brought forth another You my Lord Amphitryon, as well as I Soſia have brought forth another Me Soſia. and our Diamonds may have procreated theſe Diamonds; and ſo we are all three double,

sp.speaker: Phaedra.
sp.p: If this be true, I hope my Goblet has gigg'd another Golden Goblet: and then they may carry double upon all four.

sp.speaker: Alcm.
sp.l: My Lord, I have ſtood ſilent, out of wonder
What you cou'd wonder at.

sp.speaker: Amph.
sp.l: A chilling Sweat, a damp of Iealouſie▪
Hangs on my Brows, and clams upon my Limbs.
I fear; and yet I muſt be ſatisfied:
And, to be ſatisfy'd, I muſt diſſemble.

sp.speaker: Alcm.
sp.l: Why muſe you ſo, and murmur to your ſelf?
If you repent your Bounty, take it back▪

sp.speaker: Amph.
sp.l: Not ſo: but, if you pleaſe, relate what paſt,
At our laſt Enterview.

sp.speaker: Alcm.
sp.l: That Queſtion wou'd infer you were not here.

sp.speaker: Amph.
sp.l: I ſay not ſo;
I only wou'd refreſh my memory;
And have my Reaſons to deſire the Story.

sp.speaker: Phaedra.
sp.l: So: This is as good ſport for me as an Examination of a great
Belly before a Magiſtrate.

sp.speaker: Alcm.
sp.l: The Story is not long: you know I met you,
Kiſs'd you, and preſt you cloſe within my Arms,
With all the tenderneſs of Wively Love.

sp.speaker: Amph.
sp.l: I cou'd have ſpar'd that Kindneſs.
And what did I?

sp.speaker: Alcm.
sp.l: You ſtrain'd me with a Mafculine Embrace;
As you wou'd ſqueeze my Soul out.

sp.speaker: Amph.
sp.l: Did I ſo?

sp.speaker: Alcm.
sp.l: You did.

sp.speaker: Amph.
sp.l: Confound thoſe Arms that were ſo kind—
Proceed, proceed.—

sp.speaker: Alcm.
sp.p: You wou'd not ſtay to ſup; but, much complaining of your drowſineſs, and want of natural Reſt—

sp.speaker: Amph.
sp.l: Made haſte to Bed: Ha, was't not ſo? Go on—
And ſtab me with each Syllable thou ſpeak'ſt.

sp.speaker: Phaedra.
sp.l: So, now 'tis coming, now 'tis coming.

sp.speaker: Alcm.
sp.l: I have no more to ſay.

sp.speaker: Amph.
sp.l: Why, went we not to Bed?

sp.speaker: Alcm.
sp.l: Why not?
Is it a Crime for Husband and for Wife▪
To go to Bed, My Lord?

sp.speaker: Amph.
sp.l: Perfidious Woman!

sp.speaker: Alcm.
sp.l: Ungrateſul Man!

sp.speaker: Amph.
sp.l: She juſtifies it too!

sp.speaker: Alcm.
sp.l: I need not juſtifie: Of what am I accus'd?

sp.speaker: Amph.
sp.l: Of all that prodigality of Kindneſs,
Giv'n to another, and uſurp'd from me.
So bleſs me Heav'n, if ſince my firſt departure,
I ever ſet my foot upon this Threſhold.
So am I innocent of all thoſe Joys,
And dry of thoſe Embraces.

sp.speaker: Alcm.
sp.l: Then I, it ſeems, am falſe?

sp.speaker: Amph.
sp.l: As ſurely falſe, as what thou ſay'ſt is true.

sp.speaker: Alcm.
sp.l: I have betray'd my Honour, and my Love?
And am a foul Adultreſs?

sp.speaker: Amph.
sp.l: What thou art,
Thou ſtand'ſt condemn'd to be, by thy Relation.

sp.speaker: Alcm.
sp.l: Go, thou unworthy Man; for ever go:
No more my Husband; go thou baſe Impoſtour;
Who tak'ſt a vile pretence to taint my Fame;
And, not content to leave, wouldſt ruine me.
Enjoy thy wiſh'd Divorce: I will not plead
My Innocence, of this pretended Crime:
I need not; ſpet thy Venom; do thy worſt:
But know, the more thou wou'dſt expoſe my Vertue,
Like pureſt Linen laid in open Air,
'Twill bleach the more, and whiten to the view.

sp.speaker: Amph.
sp.l: 'Tis well thou art prepar'd for thy Divorce:
For, know thou too, that after this Affront,
This foul Indignity, done to my Honour,
Divorcement is but petty Reparation:
But, ſince thou haſt, with Impudence affirm'd
My falſe Return, and brib'd my Slaves to vouch it,
The Truth ſhall, in the face of Thebes be clear'd;
Thy Unkle, the Companion of my Voyage,
And all the Crew of Sea-men, ſhall be brought,
Who were embark'd, and came with me to Land;
Nor parted, till I reach'd this curſed Door:
So ſhall this Viſion of my late Return,
Stand a detected • ye; and woe to thoſe
Who thus betray'd my Honour.

sp.speaker: Soſia.
sp.l: Sir, Shall I wait on you?

sp.speaker: Amph.
sp.l: No, I will go alone: Expect me here.

sp.speaker: Phaedra.
sp.l: Pleaſe you—that I—

sp.speaker: Alcm.
sp.l: Oh! Nothing now can pleaſe me:
Darkneſs, and Solitude, and Sighs, and Tears,
And all th'inſeparable Train of Grief,
Attend my Steps for ever—

sp.speaker: Soſia.
sp.p: What if I ſhou'd lye now, and ſay we have been here before? I never ſaw any good that came of telling truth.

sp.speaker: Phaedra.
sp.p: He makes no more Advances to me: I begin a little to ſuſpect, that my Gold Goblet will prove but Copper.

sp.speaker: Soſia.
sp.p: Yes, 'tis reſolv'd, I will lye abominably, againſt the Light of my own Conſcience. For ſuppoſe the tother Soſia has been here: perhaps that ſtrong Dog has not only beaten me, but alſo has been predominant upon my Wife, and moſt carnally miſus'd her! Now, by asking certain Queſtions of her, with a Side-Wind, I may come to underſtand how Squares go; and whether my Nuptial Bed be violated.

sp.speaker: Phaedra.
sp.p: Moſt certainly he has learn'd Impudence of his Maſter; and will deny his being here: but that ſhall not ſerve his turn, to cheat me of my Preſent!— [Aſide. Why Soſia! What, in a brown Study?

sp.speaker: Soſia.
sp.l: A little cogitabund, or ſo; concerning this diſmal Revolution in our Family!

sp.speaker: Phaedra.
sp.p: But that ſhou'd not make you neglect your duty to me, your Miſtreſs.

sp.speaker: Soſia.
sp.p: Pretty Soul; I wou'd thou wert: upon condition that old Bromia were ſix Foot under ground.

sp.speaker: Phaedra.
sp.p: What! Is all your hot Courtſhip to me, dwindl'd into a poor unprofitable Wiſh? You may remember, I did not bid you abſolutely deſpair.

sp.speaker: Soſia.
sp.p: No; for all things yet may be accommodated, in an amicable manner, betwixt my Maſter and my Lady.

sp.speaker: Phaedra.
sp.p: I mean, to the Buſineſs, betwixt you and me—

sp.speaker: Soſia.
sp.p: Why, I hope we two never quarrell'd?

sp.speaker: Phaed.
sp.p: Muſt I remember you of a certain Promiſe that you made me at our laſt parting?

sp.speaker: Soſia.
sp.p: Oh, when I went to the Army: that I ſhou'd ſtill be praiſing thy Beauty to Judge Gripus, and keep up his Affections to thee.

sp.speaker: Phaed.
sp.p: No, I mean the Buſineſs betwixt you and me this Morning—: that you promis'd me—

sp.speaker: Soſia.
sp.p: That I promis'd thee.—I find it now: That ſtrong Dog, my Brother Soſia, has been here before me, and made Love to her.

sp.speaker: Phaed.
sp.p: You are conſidering, whether or no, you ſhould keep your Promiſe—

sp.speaker: Soſia.
sp.p: That I ſhou'd keep my Promiſe.—The truth on't is, ſhe's anothergheſs Morſel than old Bromia.

sp.speaker: Phaed.
sp.p: And I had rather you ſhould break it, in a manner, and, as it were, and in ſome Senſe.—

sp.speaker: Soſia.
sp.p: In a manner, and as it were, and in ſome Senſe, thou ſay'ſt?—I find, the ſtrong Dog has only tickl'd up her Imagination, and not enjoy'd her: ſo that with my own Limbs, I may perform the ſweetneſs of his Function with her. [Aſide. No, ſweet Creature, the Promiſe ſhall not be broken; but what I have undertaken, I will perform like a Man of Honour.

sp.speaker: Phaed.
sp.p: Then, you remember the Preliminaries of the Preſent—

sp.speaker: Soſia.
sp.p: Yes, yes, in groſs I do remember, ſomething; but this diſturbance of the Family, has ſomewhat ſtupify'd my Memory: Some pretty Quelque choſe, I warrant thee; ſome acceptable Toy, of ſmall value.

sp.speaker: Phaed.
sp.p: You may call a Gold Goblet, a Toy: But I put a greater value upon your Preſents.

sp.speaker: Soſia.
sp.p: A Gold Goblet, ſay'ſt thou! Yes, now I think on't, it was a kind of a Gold Goblet; as a Gratuity after Conſummation.

sp.speaker: Phaed.
sp.p: No, no; I had rather make ſure of one Bribe before hand, than be promis'd ten Gratuities.

sp.speaker: Soſia.
sp.p: Yes, now I remember, it was, in ſome Senſe, a Gold Goblet, by way of Earneſt; and it contain'd—

sp.speaker: Phaed.
sp.p: One large—

sp.speaker: Soſia.
sp.p: How, one large—

sp.speaker: Phaed.
sp.p: Gallon.

sp.speaker: Soſia.
sp.p:
No; that was ſomewhat too large, in Conſcience: It was not a whole Gallon; but it may contain, reaſonably ſpeaking, one large—Thimble-full:
But Gallons and Thimble-fulls are ſo like, that in ſpeaking, I might eaſily miſtake them.

sp.speaker: Phaed.
sp.p: Is it come to this? Out Traytor!

sp.speaker: Soſia.
sp.p: I had been a Traytor, indeed, to have betray'd thee to the ſwallowing of a Gallon: but a Thimblefull of Cordial-water, is eaſily ſipt off: and then, this ſame Goblet, is ſo very light too, that it will be no Burthen, to carry it about with thee, in thy Pocket.

sp.speaker: Phaed.
sp.p: O Apoſtate to thy Love! O perjur'd Villain! [Enter Bromia. What, are you here, Bromia! I was telling him his own: I was giving him a Rattle for his Treacheries to you, his Love: You ſee I can be a Friend, upon occaſion.

sp.speaker: Brom.
sp.p: Ay, Chicken, I never doubted of thy Kindneſs: but, for this Fugitive▪—this Rebel,—this Miſcreant.—

sp.speaker: Soſia.
sp.p: A kind Welcome, to an abſent Lover, as I have been.

sp.speaker: Brom.
sp.p: Ay; and a kind Greeting you gave me, at your Return; when you us'd me ſo barbarouſly, this Morning.

sp.speaker: Soſia.
sp.p: The t'other Soſia has been with her too: and has us'd her barbarouſly: barbarouſly, that is to ſay, uncivilly: and uncivilly; I am afraid that means, too civilly.

sp.speaker: Phaed.
sp.p: You had beſt deny you were here this Morning! And by the ſame Token—

sp.speaker: Soſia.
sp.p: Nay, no more Tokens, for Heaven's ſake, dear Phaedra.
Now muſt I ponder with my ſelf a little, whether it be better for me, to have been here, or not to have been here, this Morning.

sp.speaker: Servant.
sp.p: Phaedra, My Lord's without; and will not enter till he has firſt ſpoken with you.

sp.speaker: Phaed
sp.p: Oh that I could ſtay to help worry thee for this Abuſe: To him in private. but the beſt on't is, I leave thee in good hands—Farewell Thimble.—To him, Bromia.

sp.speaker: Brom.
sp.p: No; you did not beat me, and put me into a Swound, and deprive me of the natural uſe of my Tongue for a long Half-hour: You did not beat me down, with your little Wand: But I ſhall teach you to uſe your Rod another time—I ſhall.

sp.speaker: Soſia.
sp.p: Put her into a Swound, with my little Wand, and ſo forth: That's more than ever I cou'd do. Theſe are terrible Circumſtances that ſome Soſia or another, has been here: Now, if he has literally beaten her, Grammercy, Brother Soſia; he has but done, what I wou'd have done, if I had durſt: But I am afraid it was only a damn'd Love-figure; and that the Wand that lay'd her aſleep, might ſignifie the Peace-maker.

sp.speaker: Brom.
sp.p: Now you are ſnuffling upon a cold Scent, for ſome pitiful Excuſe: I know you: twenty to one, but you will plead a Drunkenneſs: You are usd to be pot-valiant.

sp.speaker: Soſia.
sp.p: I was pumping, and I thank her, ſhe has invented for me.—Yes▪ Bromia, I muſt confeſs I was exalted: and, poſſibly, I might ſcoure upon thee, or perhaps be a little more familiar with thy perſon, by the way of Kindneſs, than if I had been ſober; but, prithee, inform me what I did; that I may conſider what ſatisfaction I am to make thee.

sp.speaker: Bromia.
sp.p: Are you there, at your Dog-tricks! You wou'd be forgetting, wou'd you? like a drunken Bully that affronts over-night, and, when he is call'd to account, the next Morning, remembers nothing of the Quarrel; and asks pardon, to avoid fighting.

sp.speaker: Soſia.
sp.p: By Bacchus, I was overtaken; but I ſhou'd be loth that I committed any folly with thee.

sp.speaker: Bromia.
sp.p: I am ſure, I kept my ſelf awake all night, that I did, in expectation of your coming.

sp.speaker: Soſia.
sp.p: But what amends did I make thee, when I came!

sp.speaker: Bromia.
sp.p: You know well enough, to my ſorrow; but that you play the Hypocrite.

sp.speaker: Soſia.
sp.p: I warrant, I was monſtrous kind to thee.—

sp.speaker: Brom.
sp.p: Yes, monſtrous kind indeed: You never ſaid a truer word: for, when I came to kiſs you, you pull'd away your Mouth, and turn'd your Cheek to me.

sp.speaker: Soſia.
sp.p: Good.

sp.speaker: Brom.
sp.p: How, Good! Here's fine Impudence: He juſtifies!—.

sp.speaker: Soſia.
sp.p: Yes, I do juſtifie, that I turn'd my Cheek, like a prudent perſon, that my Breath might not offend thee: for, now I remember, I had eaten Garlick.

sp.speaker: Brom.
sp.p: Ay, you remember, and forget, juſt as it makes for you, or againſt you: but, to mend the matter, you never ſpoke one civil word to me: but ſtood like a ſtock, without ſenſe or motion.

sp.speaker: Soſia.
sp.p: Yet better.

sp.speaker: Brom.
sp.p: After which, I lovingly invited you to take your place in your Nuptial Bed, as the Laws of Matrimony oblige you: and you inhumanly refus'd me.

sp.speaker: Soſia.
sp.p: Ay, there's the main point of the Buſineſs! Art thou morally certain, that I refus'd thee: Look me now in the ſace, and ſay I did not commit Matrimony with thee!

sp.speaker: Brom.
sp.p: I wonder how thou canſt look me in the face, after that refuſal!

sp.speaker: Soſia.
sp.p: Say it once again, that I did not feloniouſly come to Bed to thee!

sp.speaker: Brom.
sp.p: No, thou cold Traytor, thou know'ſt thou didſt not.

sp.speaker: Soſia.
sp.p: Beſt of all; 'twas diſcreetly done of me to abſtain.

sp.speaker: Brom.
sp.p: What do you inſult upon me too!

sp.speaker: Soſia.
sp.p: No, I do not inſult upon you;—but—

sp.speaker: Brom.
sp.p: But what? How was it diſcreetly done then? Ha!

sp.speaker: Soſia.
sp.p: Becauſe it is the receiv'd Opinion of Phyſicians, that nothing but puling Chitts, and Booby-Fools, are procreated in Drunkenneſs.

sp.speaker: Brom.
sp.p:
A receiv'd Opinion, Snivel-guts! I'll be judg'd by all the marry'd Women of this Town, if any one of 'em has receiv'd it: The Devil take the Phyſicians, for medling in our Matters: If a Husband will be rul'd by them, there are five weeks of Abſtinence in Dog-days too; for fear a Child that was
got in Auguſt, ſhould be born juſt nine Months after, and be blear-ey'd, like a May-Kitten.

sp.speaker: Soſia.
sp.p: Let the Phyſicians alone; they are honeſt Men, whatever the World ſays of 'em. But, for a certain reaſon, that I beſt know, I am glad that Matter ended ſo fairly and peaceably betwixt us.

sp.speaker: Brom.
sp.p: Yes 'twas very fair and peaceable: to ſtrike a Woman down, and beat her moſt outrageouſly.

sp.speaker: Soſia.
sp.p: Is it poſſible that I drubb'd thee!

sp.speaker: Brom.
sp.p: I find your drift: You wou'd fain be provoking me to a new Trial now: but, i'faith, you ſhall bring me to no more handy-blows: I ſhall make bold to truſt to my Tongue hereafter: You never durſt have offer'd to hold up a finger againſt me, till you went a Trooping.

sp.speaker: Soſia.
sp.p: Then I am a Conqueror: and I laud my own Courage: This Renown I have atchiev'd by Souldierſhip and Stratagem. Know your Duty, Spouſe, henceſorward to your ſupream Commander.

div.stage: Enter Jupiter and Phaedra, attended by Muſicians and Dancers.

sp.speaker: Phaedra.
sp.p: Indeed I wondred at your quick return.

sp.speaker: Jup.
sp.l: Ev'n ſo Almighty Love will have it, Phaedra;
And the ſtern Goddeſs of ſweet-bitter Cares,
Who bows our Necks beneath her brazen Yoke.
I wou'd have mann'd my heart, and held it out;
But, when I thought of what I had poſſeſt;
Thoſe joys, that never end, but to begin,
O, I am all on fire to make my peace:
And die, Jove knows, as much as I can die,
Till I am reconcil'd.

sp.speaker: Phaed.
sp.p: I fear 'twill be in vain.

sp.speaker: Jup.
sp.l: 'Tis difficult:
But nothing is impoſſible to Love:
To Love like mine; for I have prov'd his force,
And my Alcmena too has felt his Dart.
If I ſubmit, there's hope.

sp.speaker: Phaed.
sp.p: 'Tis poſſible I may ſollicit for you.

sp.speaker: Jup.
sp.p: But wilt thou promiſe me to do thy hoſt?

sp.speaker: Phaed.
sp.l: Nay I promiſe nothing—unleſs you begin
To promiſe firſt.—

sp.speaker: Jup.
sp.p: I wou'not be ungrateful.

sp.speaker: Phaed.
sp.p: Well; I'll try to bring her to the Window: You ſhall have a fair ſhoot at her: if you can bring her down, you are a good Markes-man.

sp.speaker: Jup.
sp.l: That's all I ask:
And I will ſo reward thee, Gentle Phaedra.—

sp.speaker: Phaed.
sp.p: What, with Cats-guts and Roſin! This Sol-la; is but a lamentable, empty, ſound.

sp.speaker: Jup.
sp.p: Then there's a ſound will pleaſe thee better.

sp.speaker: Phaed.
sp.l: Ay, there's ſomething of Melody in this ſound.
I cou'd dance all day, to the Muſick of Chink▪ Chink.

sp.speaker: Jup.
sp.l: Go Soſia round our Thebes,
To Polydas, to Tranio, and to Gripus,
Companions of our War; invite 'em all,
To joyn their Pray'rs to ſmooth Alomena's Brow;
And, with a ſolemn Feaſt, to crown the day.

sp.speaker: Soſia.
sp.p: Let me embrace you, Sir.—

Nay, you muſt give me leave to expreſs my Gratitude; I have not eaten, to ſay eating, nor drunk, to ſay drinking, never ſince our villanous encamping ſo near the Enemy: 'Tis true, I ſcap'd the bloody-Flux, becauſe I bad ſo little in my Bowels to come out▪ and I durſt let nothing go, in Conſcience, becauſe I had nothing to ſwallow in the room on't.

sp.speaker: Jup.
sp.l: You, Bromia, ſee that all things be prepar'd,
With that Magniſicence, as if ſome God
Were Gueſt, or Maſter here.

sp.speaker: Soſia.
sp.p: Or rather, as much, as if twenty Gods were to be Gueſts, or Maſters here.

sp.speaker: Brom.
sp.p: That you may eat for to day, and to morrow.

sp.speaker: Soſia.
sp.p: Or, rather again, for to day and yeſterday; and as many Months backwards, as I am indebted to my own Belly▪

sp.speaker: Jup.
sp.p: Away both of you.

sp.speaker: Jup.
sp.l: Now I have pack'd him hence; thou, other Soſia,
(Who, tho' thou art not preſent, hear'ſt my voice,)
Be ready to attend me at my Call;
And to ſupply his place.

sp.speaker: Jup.
sp.l: See, ſhe appears:
This is my Bribe to Phaedra; when I made
This Gold, I made a greater God than Jove,
And gave my own Omnipotence away.

div.stage: Jupiter ſigns to the Muſicians; Song and Dance: after which, Alcmena withdraws, frowning.

lg.head: I.
lg.l: CElia, that I once was bleſt

l.hi: Is now the Torment of my Breſt;
Since to curſe me, you bereave me
Of the Pleaſures I poſſeſt:
Cruel Creature, to deceive me!
Firſt to love, and then to leave me!

lg.head: II.
lg.l: Had you the Bliſs refus'd to grant,
Then I had never known the want:
But poſſeſſing once the Bleſſing,
Is the Cauſe of my Complaint:
Once poſſeſſing is but taſting;
'Tis no Bliſs that is not laſting.

lg.head: III.
lg.l: Celia now is mine no more;

l.hi: But I am hers; and muſt adore:
Nor to leave her will endeavour;
Charms, that captiv'd me before,
No unkindneſs can diſſever;
Love that's true, is Love for ever.

sp.speaker: Jup.
sp.p: O ſtay.

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.p: She's gone; and ſeem'd to ſrown at parting.

sp.speaker: Jup.
sp.l: Follow, and thou ſhalt ſee her ſoon appeas'd:
For I, who made her, know her inward ſtate;
No Woman, once well pleas'd, can throughly hate:
I gave 'em Beauty, to ſubdue the ſtrong:
(A mighty Empire, but it laſts not long:)
I gave 'em Pride to make Mankind their Slave;
But, in exchange, to Men I Flattery gave:
Th' offending Lover, when he loweſt lies,
Submits, to conquer; and but kneels, to riſe.

div.trailer: The End of the Third Act.

div.head: The FOURTH ACT.
div.stage: Jupiter following Alcmena; Mercury and Phaedra.

sp.speaker: Jupiter.
sp.l: O Stay, my dear Alcmena, hear me ſpeak.

sp.speaker: Alcm.
sp.l: No, I wou'd fly thee, to the ridge of earth,
And leap the Precipice, to ſcape thy ſight.

sp.speaker: Jup.
sp.l: For pity—

sp.speaker: Alcm.
sp.l: Leave me, thou ungrateful Man.

sp.speaker: Jup.
sp.l: I cannot leave you: no; but like a Ghoſt
Whom your Unkindneſs murder'd, will I haunt you.

sp.speaker: Alcm.
sp.l: Once more, be gone: I'm odious to my ſelf
For having lov'd thee once.

sp.speaker: Jup.
sp.l: Hate not the beſt and faireſt of your kind:
Nor can you hate your Lover, tho' you wou'd:
Your Tears, that fall ſo gently, are but grief:
There may be Anger; but there muſt be Love.
The Dove, that murmurs at her Mate's neglect,
But counterfeits a coyneſs, to be courted.

sp.speaker: Alcm.
sp.l: Courtſhip, from thee, and after ſuch affronts!

sp.speaker: Jup.
sp.l: Is this that everlaſting Love you vow'd,
Laſt Night, when I was circled in your arms?
Remember what you ſwore.—

sp.speaker: Alcm.
sp.l: Think what thou wert, and who cou'd ſwear too much?
Think what thou art, and that unſwears it all.

sp.speaker: Jup.
sp.l: Can you forſake me, for ſo ſmall a fault?
'Twas but a Jeſt, perhaps too far purſu'd:
'Twas but at moſt, a Trial of your Faith,
How you cou'd bear unkindneſs:
'Twas but to get a reconciling Kiſs,
A wanton Stratagem of Love.

sp.speaker: Alcm.
sp.l: See how he doubles, like a hunted Hare,
A Jeſt, and then a Trial, and a Bait;
All ſtuff, and dawbing!

sp.speaker: Jup.
sp.l: Think me jealous, then:

sp.speaker: Alcm.
sp.l: O that I cou'd; for that's a noble Crime;
And which a Lover can, with eaſe, forgive:
'Tis the high pulſe of Paſſion, in a Fever;
A ſickly draught, but ſhews a burning Thirſt:
Thine was a Surfeit, not a Jealouſie:
And in that loathing of thy full gorg'd Love,
Thou ſaw'ſt the nauſeous Object, with diſdain.

sp.speaker: Jup.
sp.l: O think not that: for you are ever new:
Your fruits of Love, are like eternal Spring
In happy Climes, where ſome are in the bud,
Some green, and ripening ſome, while others fall.

sp.speaker: Alcm.
sp.l: Ay, now you tell me this,
When rous'd deſires, and freſh recruits of force,
Enable languiſh'd Love to take the field.
But never hope to be receiv'd again:
You wou'd again deny you were receiv'd;
And brand my ſpotleſs Fame.

sp.speaker: Jup.
sp.l: I will not dare to juſtifie my Crime,
But only point you where to lay the blame:
Impute it to the Husband, not the Lover.

sp.speaker: Alcm.
sp.l: How vainly wou'd the Sophiſter divide,
And make the Husband and the Lover, two!

sp.speaker: Jup.
sp.l: Yes 'tis the Husband is the guilty Wretch:
His Inſolence forgot the Sweets of Love,
And, deeming them his due, deſpis'd the Feaſt.
Not ſo the famiſh'd Lover cou'd forget:
He knew he had been there, and had been bleſt,
With all that Hope can wiſh, or Senſe can bear:

sp.speaker: Alcm.
sp.l: Husband, and Lover, both alike I hate.

sp.speaker: Jup.
sp.l: And I confeſs I have deſerv'd that hate:
Too charming fair, I kneel for your forgiveneſs:
I beg by thoſe fair eyes,
Which gave me wounds, That time can never cure;
Receive my Sorrows, and reſtore my Joys.

sp.speaker: Alcm.
sp.l: Unkind, and cruel! I can ſpeak no more▪

sp.speaker: Jup.
sp.l: O give it vent Alcmena, give it vent;
I merit your reproach, I wou'd be curs'd:
Let your Tongue curſe me, while your Heart forgives.

sp.speaker: Alcm.
sp.l: Can I forget ſuch Uſage!

sp.speaker: Jup.
sp.l: Can you hate me?

sp.speaker: Alcm.
sp.l: I'll do my beſt: for ſure I ought to hate you.

sp.speaker: Jup.
sp.l: That Word was only hatch'd upon your Tongue,
It came not from your Heart. But try again,
And if, once more, you can but ſay, I hate you,
My Sword ſhall do you juſtice.

sp.speaker: Alcm.
sp.l: Then, I hate you.—

sp.speaker: Jup.
sp.l: Then you pronounce the Sentence of my Death?

sp.speaker: Alcm.
sp.l: I hate you, much; but yet I love you more.

sp.speaker: Jup.
sp.l: To prove that Love, then ſay, that you forgive me:
For there remains but this Alternative:
Reſolve to pardon, or to puniſh me.

sp.speaker: Alcm.
sp.l: Alas, what I reſolve appears too plain:
In ſaying that I cannot hate, I pardon.

sp.speaker: Jup.
sp.l: But what's a Pardon worth, without a Seal?
Permit me, in this Tranſport of my Joy—

sp.speaker: Alcm.
sp.l: Forbear; I am offended with my ſelf,
sp.stage: Putting him gently away with her Hand.
sp.l: That I have ſhewn this Weakneſs.—Let me go,
Where I may bluſh, alone.—
But come not you:
Leſt I ſhou'd ſpoil you, with exceſs of Fondneſs,
And let you love again.—

sp.speaker: Jup.
sp.l: Forbidding me to follow, ſhe invites me:
This is the Mould of which I made the Sex:
I gave 'em but one Tongue, to ſay us nay;
And two kind Eyes, to grant. Be ſure that none
Approach, to interrupt our privacy

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.p: Your Lady has made the Challenge of Reconciliation to my Lord: Here's a fair Example for us two, Phaedra.

sp.speaker: Phaed.
sp.p: No Example at all, Soſia: for my Lady had the Diamonds aforehand, and I have none of the Gold Goblet.

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.p: The Goblet ſhall be forth-coming; if thou wilt give me weight for weight.

sp.speaker: Phaed.
sp.p: Yes, and meaſure for meaſure too, Soſia: that is, For a Thimbleful of Gold, a Thimbleful of Love.

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.p: What think you now, Phaedra? Here's Pulling out the Goblet in a Caſe, from under his Cloak. a weighty Argument of Love for you.

sp.speaker: Phaed.
sp.p: Now Jupiter, of his Mercy, let me kiſs thee, O thou Taking it in both Hands. dear Metal!

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.p: And Venus, of her Mercy, let me kiſs thee, dear, dear Phaedra.

sp.speaker: Phaed.
sp.p: Not ſo faſt, Soſia! there's a damn'd Proverb in your way: Many things happen betwixt the Cup and the Lips, you know.

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.p: Why, thou wilt not cheat me of my Goblet?

sp.speaker: Phaed.
sp.p: Yes; as ſure as you wou'd cheat me of my Maiden-head: I am yet, but juſt even with you, for the laſt Trick you play'd me. And, beſides; this is but a bare Retaining Fee; you muſt give me another, before the Cauſe is open'd.

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.p: Shall I not come to your Bed ſide, to Night?

sp.speaker: Phaed.
sp.p: No, nor to Morrow-Night, neither: but this ſhall be my Sweet-heart in your place: 'tis a better Bed-fellow, and will keep me warmer, in cold Weather.

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.p:
Now, what's the God of Wit in a Woman's Hand? This very Goblet I ſtole from Gripus; and he got it out of Bribes too. But this is the common fate of ill gotten Goods, that as they came in by Covetouſneſs, they go out by Whoring.—Oh, here's Amphitryon again, but I'll
[Enter Amphitryon. manage him above, in the Balcony.

sp.speaker: Amph.
sp.l: Not one of thoſe I look'd for, to be found!
As ſome Enchantment hid 'em from my ſight!
Perhaps, as Soſia ſays, 'tis Witchcraft all:
Seals may be open'd, Diamonds may be ſtol'n;
But how I came, in perſon, yeſterday,
And gave that Preſent to Alcmena's hands,
That which I never gave, nor ever came,
O there's the Rock, on which my Reaſon ſplits:
Wou'd that were all! I fear my Honour, too!
I'll try her once again: She may be mad:
A wretched Remedy; but all I have,
To keep me from deſpair.

sp.speaker: Mercury.
sp.p: This is no very charitable Action of a God, to [From the Balcony, uſe him ill, who has never offended me: but my Planet (Aſide. net diſpoſes me to Malice: and when we great Perſons do but a little Miſchief, the World has a good bargain of us.

sp.speaker: Amph.
sp.p: How now! what means the locking up of my Doors, at this time of day?

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.p: Softly, Friend, ſoftly: You knock as loud, and as ſawcily, as a Lord's Footman, that was ſent before him, to warn the Family of his Honour's Viſit. Sure you think the Doors have no feeling! What the Devil are you, that rap with ſuch Authority?

sp.speaker: Amph.
sp.p: Look out, and ſee: 'tis I.

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.p: You: What You?

sp.speaker: Amph.
sp.p: No more, I ſay, but open.

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.p: I'll know to whom firſt?

sp.speaker: Amph.
sp.p: I am one that can command the doors open.

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.p: Then you had beſt command 'em, and try whether they will obey You.

sp.speaker: Amph.
sp.p: Doſt thou not know me!

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.p: Prithee, how ſhou'd I know thee? Doſt thou take me for a Conjurer?

sp.speaker: Amph.
sp.p: What's this Midſummer-Moon? Is all the World gone a madding? Why Soſia!

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.p: That's my Name indeed: Didſt thou think I had forgot it!

sp.speaker: Amph.
sp.p: Doſt thou ſee me?

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.p: Why, doſt thou pretend to go inviſible? If thou haſt any buſineſs here, diſpatch it quickly; I have no leaſure to throw away upon ſuch pratling Companions.

sp.speaker: Amph.
sp.p: Thy Companion, Slave? How dar'ſt thou uſe this inſolent Language to thy Maſter!

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.p: How! Thou my Maſter? By what Title? I never had any other Maſter, but Amphitryon.

sp.speaker: Amph.
sp.p: Well: and for whom doſt thou take me?

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.p: For ſome Rogue or other; but what Rogue I know not.

sp.speaker: Amph.
sp.p: Doſt thou not know me for Amphitryon, Slave!

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.p: How ſhou'd I know thee, when I ſee thou doſt not know thy ſelf! thou Amphitryon? In what Tavern haſt thou been? And how many Bottles did thy buſineſs, to metamorphoſe thee into my Lord?

sp.speaker: Amph.
sp.p: I will ſo drub thee, for this inſolence.

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.p: How now, Impudence! are you threatning your Betters! I ſhou'd bring you to condign puniſhment, but that I have a great reſpect for the good Wine, though I find it in a Fool's Noddle.

sp.speaker: Amph.
sp.p: What, none to let me in? Why Phaedra! Bromia!

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.p: Peace Fellow; if my Wife hears thee, we are both undone. At a word, Phaedra and Bromia are very buſie; one in making a Cawdle for my Lady; and the other in heating Napkins, to rub down my Lord, when he riſes from Bed.

sp.speaker: Amph.
sp.p: Amazement ſeizes me.

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.p: At what art thou amaz'd? My Maſter and my Lady had a falling out, and are retir'd, without Seconds, to decide the Quarrel. If thou wert not a meddleſome Fool, thou woud'ſt not be thruſting thy Noſe into other Peoples Matters. Get thee about thy buſineſs, if thou haſt any; for I'll hear no more of thee.

sp.speaker: Amph.
sp.l: Brav'd by my Slave, diſhonour'd by my Wife,
To what a deſp'rate plunge am I reduc'd,
If this be true the Villain ſays? But why
That feeble, If! It muſt be true; She owns it.
Now, whether to conceal, or blaze th' Affront?
One way, I ſpread my infamy abroad;
And, t'other, hide a burning coal, within;
That preys upon my Vitals: I can fix
On nothing, but on Vengeance.

div.stage: Enter to him Soſia, Polydas, Gripus, Tranio.

sp.speaker: Gripus.
sp.p: Yonder he is; walking haſtily to and fro, before his door; like a Citizen, clapping his Sides before his Shop, in a froſty Morning: 'tis to catch a Stomach, I believe.

sp.speaker: Soſia.
sp.p: I begin to be affraid, that he has more ſtomach to my Sides, and Shoulders, than to his own Victuals. How he ſhakes his head! and ſtamps, and what ſtrides he fetches! He's in one of his damn'd Moods again; I don't like the Looks of him.

sp.speaker: Amph
sp.p: Oh, my mannerly, fair-ſpoken, obedient Slave, are you there! I can reach you now, without climbing: Now we ſhall try who's drunk, and who's ſober.

sp.speaker: Soſia.
sp.p: Why this is as it ſhou'd be: I was ſomewhat ſuſpicious that you were in a peſtilent humour; Yes, we will have a craſh at the Bottle, when your Lordſhip pleaſes: I have ſummo'nd 'em, you ſee; and they are notable Topers; eſpecially Judge Gripus.

sp.speaker: Grip.
sp.p: Yes, 'faith; I never refuſe my Glaſs, in a good Quarrel.

sp.speaker: Amph.
sp.p: Why, thou inſolent Villain; I'll teach a Slave how to uſe his Maſter thus.

sp.speaker: Soſia.
sp.p: Here's a fine buſineſs towards! I am ſure I ran as faſt as ever my legs cou'd carry me, to call 'em: nay you may truſt my diligence, in all affairs belonging to the belly.

sp.speaker: Grip.
sp.p: He has been very faithfull to his Commiſſion, I'll bear him witneſs.

sp.speaker: Amph.
sp.p: How can you be witneſs, where you were not preſent? the Balcony! Sirrah, the Balcony!

sp.speaker: Soſia.
sp.p: Why, to my beſt remembrance, you never invited the Balcony.

sp.speaker: Amph.
sp.p: What nonſence doſt thou plead for an Excuſe, of thy foul language, and thy baſe replies!

sp.speaker: Soſia.
sp.p: You fright a man out of his ſenſes, firſt; and blame him, afterwards, for talking nonſence:—but 'tis better for me to talk nonſence, than for ſome to do nonſence: I will ſay that, what e'er comes on't. Pray Sir, let all things be done decently: what, I hope, when a man is to be hang'd, he is not truſs'd upon the Gallows, like a dumb Dog, without telling him wherefore.

sp.speaker: Amph.
sp.p: By your pardon, Gentlemen: I have no longer patience to forbear him.

sp.speaker: Soſia.
sp.p: Juſtice, juſtice, my Lord Gripus: as you are a true Magiſtrate, protect me. Here's a proceſs of Beating going forward, without ſentence given.

sp.speaker: Grip.
sp.p: My Lord Amphitryon, this muſt not be: Let me firſt underſtand the demerits of the Criminal.

sp.speaker: Soſia.
sp.p: Hold you to that point, I beſeech your Honour, as you commiſerate the Caſe of a poor, innocent Malefactour.

sp.speaker: Amph.
sp.p: To ſhut the door againſt me, in my very face, to deny me entrance, to brave me from the Balcony, to laugh at me, to threaten me: what proofs of Innocence call you theſe? but if I puniſh not this Inſolence— [Is going to beat him and is held by Polydas and Tranio. I beg you let me go—

sp.speaker: Soſia.
sp.p: I charge you in the King's name, hold him faſt; for you ſee he's bloodily diſpos'd.

sp.speaker: Grip.
sp.p: Now, what haſt thou to ſay for thy ſelf, Soſia?

sp.speaker: Soſia.
sp.p: I ſay, in the firſt place, be ſure you hold him, Gentlemen; for I ſhall never plead worth one farthing, while I am bodily affraid.

sp.speaker: Polyd.
sp.p: Speak boldly; I warrant thee.

sp.speaker: Soſia.
sp.p: Then, if I may ſpeak boldly, under my Lord's favour, I do not ſay he lyes neither: no, I am too well bred for that: but his Lordſhip fibbs moſt abominably.

sp.speaker: Amph.
sp.p: Do you hear his Impudence? yet will you let me go?

sp.speaker: Soſia.
sp.p: No Impudence at all, my Lord: for how cou'd I, naturally ſpeaking, be in the Balcony, and affronting you; when at the ſame time I was in every Street of Thebes, inviting theſe Gentlemen to Dinner?

sp.speaker: Grip.
sp.p: Hold a little: how long ſince was it that he ſpoke to you, from the ſaid Balcony?

sp.speaker: Amph.
sp.p: Juſt now; not a Minute before he brought you hither.

sp.speaker: Soſia.
sp.p: Now ſpeak my Witneſſes.

sp.speaker: Grip.
sp.p: I can anſwer for him, for this laſt half hour.

sp.speaker: Soſia.
sp.p: Now judge equitably, Gentlemen; whether I was not a civil well-bred perſon, to tell my Lord he fibbs onely.

sp.speaker: Amph.
sp.p: Who gave you that order, to invite 'em?

sp.speaker: Soſia.
sp.p: He that beſt might; your ſelf: by the ſame token, you bid old Bromia provide and 'twere for a God; and I put in for a brace, or a leaſe; no, now I think on't, it was for ten couple of Gods, to make ſure of plenty.

sp.speaker: Amph.
sp.p: When did I give thee this pretended Commiſſion?

sp.speaker: Soſia.
sp.p: Why you gave me this pretended Commiſſion, when you were juſt ready to give my Lady the Fiddles and a Dance; in order, as I ſuppoſe, to your ſecond bedding.

sp.speaker: Amph.
sp.p: Where, in what place, did I give this order?

sp.speaker: Soſia.
sp.p: Here, in this place; in the preſence of this very door, and of that Balcony: and if they cou'd ſpeak, they wou'd both juſtifie it.

sp.speaker: Amph.
sp.p: O Heaven! theſe accidents are ſo ſurprizing, that the more I think of 'em, the more I am loſt in my imagination.

sp.speaker: Grip.
sp.p: Nay, he has told us ſome paſſages, as he came along, that ſeem to ſurpaſs the power of Nature.

sp.speaker: Soſia.
sp.p: What think you now, my Lord, of a certain twin Brother of mine, call'd Soſia? 'tis a ſly Youth: pray Heaven you have not juſt ſuch another Relation, within doors, call'd Amphitryon. It may be it was he, that put upon me, in your likeneſs: and perhaps he may have put ſomething upon your Lordſhip too, that may weigh heavy upon the forehead.

sp.speaker: Amph.
sp.p: Let me go:—Soſia may be innocent, and I will not hurt him:—Open the door; I'll reſolve my doubts immediately.

sp.speaker: Soſia.
sp.p: The door is peremptory, that it will not be open'd without Keys: and my Brother, on the inſide, is in poſſeſſion; and will not part with 'em.

sp.speaker: Amph.
sp.p: Then 'tis manifeſt that I am affronted; break open the door there.

sp.speaker: Grip.
sp.p: Stir not a man of you, to his aſſiſtance.

sp.speaker: Amph.
sp.p: Doſt thou take part with my Adultreſs too, becauſe ſhe is thy Niece?

sp.speaker: Grip.
sp.p: I take part with nothing, but the Law; and, to break the doors open, is to break the Law.

sp.speaker: Amph.
sp.p: Do thou command 'em, then.

sp.speaker: Grip.
sp.p: I command nothing without my Warrant; and my Clerk is not here to take his Fees for drawing it.

sp.speaker: Amph.
sp.p: The Devil take all Juſtice-brokers:—I curſe him too when I have been hunting him all over the Town, to be my Witneſs!—But I'll bring Souldiers to force open the doors, by my own Commiſſion.

sp.speaker: Soſia.
sp.p: Pox o'theſe forms of Law, to defeat a man of a Dinner, when he's ſharp ſet: 'tis againſt the priviledge of a free-born Stomack; and is no leſs than ſubverſion of Fundamentals. [Jupiter above in the Balcony.

sp.speaker: Jupit.
sp.p: Oh, my Friends, I am ſorry I have made you wait ſo long: you are welcome; and the door ſhall be open'd to you, immediately.

sp.speaker: Grip.
sp.p: Was not that Amphitryon?

sp.speaker: Soſia.
sp.p: Why, who ſhou'd it be elſe?

sp.speaker: Grip.
sp.p: In all appearance it was he: but how got he thither?

sp.speaker: Polyd.
sp.p: In ſuch a trice too!

sp.speaker: Tran.
sp.p: And after he had juſt left us?

sp.speaker: Grip.
sp.p: And ſo much alter'd, for the better, in his humour?

sp.speaker: Soſia.
sp.p: Here's ſuch a company of fooliſh queſtions, when a man's a hungry: You had beſt ſtay dinner till he has prov'd himſelf to be Amphitryon in form of Law: But I'll make ſhort work of that buſineſs: for I'll take mine Oath 'tis he.

sp.speaker: Grip.
sp.p: I ſhou'd be glad it were.

sp.speaker: Soſia.
sp.p: How glad it were? with your damn'd Interrogatories, when you ought to be thankfull, that ſo it is.

sp.speaker: Grip.
sp.p: That I may ſee my Miſtreſs Phoedra, and preſent her with my great gold Gobblet.

sp.speaker: Soſia,
sp.p: If this be not the true Amphitryon, I wiſh I may be kept without doors, faſting, and biting my own Fingers, for want of Victuals; and that's a dreadfull Imprecation! I am for the inviting, and eating, and treating Amphitryon: I am ſure 'tis he that is my lawfully begotten Lord: and if you had an Ounce of true Juſtice in you, you ought to have laid hold on t'other Amphitryon, and committed him for a Rogue, and an Impoſtour, and a Vagabond.

div.stage: [The Door is open'd: Mercury from within.

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.p: Enter quickly, Maſters: The Paſſage on the right-hand leads to the Gallery, where my Lord expects you:—for I am call'd another way.

div.stage: [Gripus, Tranio, and Polydas go into the Houſe.

sp.speaker: Soſia.
sp.p: I ſhou'd know that Voice, by a ſecret Inſtinct: 'tis a Tongue of my Family; and belongs to my Brother Soſia: it muſt be ſo; for it carries a cudgelling kind of ſound in it.—But put the worſt: let me weigh this matter wiſely: Here's a beating, and a belly-full: againſt no beating, and no belly-full. The beating is bad; but the dinner is good: now, not to be beaten, is but negatively good; but, not to ſill my belly, is poſitively bad.—Upon the whole matter, my final reſolution is, to take the good and the bad as they come together.
sp.stage: [Is entring: Mercury meets him at the Door.

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.p: Whither now, you kitchen-skumm? From whence this Impudence, to enter here without permiſſion?

sp.speaker: Soſia,
sp.p: Moſt Illuſtrious Sir: my Ticket is my hunger: ſhew the full Bowe's of your Compaſſion, to the empty bowels of my famine.

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.p: Were you not charg'd to return no more? I'll cut you into quarters, and hang you upon the Shambles.

sp.speaker: Soſia.
sp.p: You'll get but little credit by me: Alas, Sir, I am but mere Carrion! Brave Soſia, compaſſionate Coward Soſia: and beat not thy ſelf, in beating me.

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.p: Who gave you that privilege, Sirrah, to aſſume my Name? have you not been ſufficiently warn'd of it? and receiv'd part of puniſhment already?

sp.speaker: Soſia.
sp.p: May it pleaſe you, Sir, the Name is big enough for both of us: and we may uſe it in common, like a Strumpet: witneſs heaven, that I wou'd have obey'd you, and quitted my Title to the name; but, where ever I come, the malicious world will call me Soſia, in ſpight of me: I am ſenſible there are two Amphitryons; and why may not there be two Soſia's? Let thoſe two cut one anothers throats at their own pleaſure: but you and I will be wiſer, by my conſent, and hold good Intelligence together.

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.p: No, no: Two Soſia's wou'd but make two fools.

sp.speaker: Soſia.
sp.p: Then let me be the fool; and be you the prudent perſon: and chuſe for your ſelf ſome wiſer name: or you ſhall be the Elder Brother; and I'll be content to be the Younger; though I loſe my Inheritance.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: I tell thee, I am the onely Son of our Family.

sp.speaker: Soſia.
sp.p: Then let me be your Baſtard Brother, and the Son of a Whore; I hope that's but reaſonable.

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.p: No, Thou ſhalt not diſgrace my Father: For there are few Baſtards now-a-days worth owning.

sp.speaker: Soſia.
sp.p: Ah! Poor Soſia! What will become of thee?

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.p: Yet again profanely uſing my proper name?

sp.speaker: Soſia.
sp.p: I did not mean my ſelf: I was thinking of another Soſia, a poor fellow, that was once of my acquaintance, unfortunately baniſh'd out of doors, when dinner was juſt coming upon the Table.

sp.speaker: Phaed.
sp.p: Soſia, you and I muſt—Bleſs me! What have we here, a Couple of you, or do I ſee double?

sp.speaker: Soſia.
sp.p: I wou'd fain bring it about, that I might make one of 'em: But he's unreaſonable and will needs incorporate me, and ſwallow me whole into himſelf. If he wou'd be content to be but one and a half, 'twou'd never grieve me.

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.p: 'Tis a perverſe Raſcal: I kick him, and cudgel him to no purpoſe: for ſtill he's obſtinate to ſtick to me: and I can never beat him out of my reſemblance.

sp.speaker: Phaed.
sp.p: Which of you two is Soſia? For t'other muſt be the Devil.

sp.speaker: Soſia.
sp.p: You had beſt ask him that has play'd the Devil with my back and ſides.

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.p: You had beſt ask him who gave you the gold Gobblet?

sp.speaker: Phaed.
sp.p: No, that's already given: but he ſhall be my Soſia, that will give me ſuch another.

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.p: I ſind you have been Interloping, Sirrah.

sp.speaker: Soſia.
sp.p: No, indeed, Sir; I onely promiſed her a gold Thimble: which was as much as comes to my proportion of being Soſia.

sp.speaker: Phaed.
sp.p: This is no Soſia for my money: beat him away t'other Soſia: he grows inſufferable.

sp.speaker: Soſia.
sp.p: Wou'd I were valiant, that I might beat him away; and ſucceed him at the dinner; for a pragmatical Son of a Whore, as he is—

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.p: What's that you are muttering betwixt your Teeth, of a Son of a Whore, Sirrah?

sp.speaker: Soſia.
sp.p: I am ſure I meant you no offence: for, if I am not Soſia, I am the Son of a Whore, for ought I know: and, if you are Soſia, you may be the Son of a Whore for ought you know.

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.p: What ever I am, I will be Soſia, as long as I pleaſe: and whenever you viſit me, you ſhall be ſure of the civility of the Cudgel.

sp.speaker: Soſia.
sp.p: If you will promiſe to beat me into the houſe, you may begin when you pleaſe with me: but, to be beaten out of the houſe, at dinner time, fleſh and bloud can never bear it.

div.stage: Mercury beats him about, and Soſia is ſtill making towards the door: but Mercury gets betwixt; and at length drives him off the Stage.

sp.speaker: Phaed.
sp.p: In the name of wonder, what are you, that are Soſia, and are not Soſia?

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.p: If thou would'ſt know more of me, my perſon is freely at thy diſpoſing.

sp.speaker: Phaed.
sp.p: Then I diſpoſe of it to you again: for 'tis ſo ugly, 'tis not for my uſe.

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.p: I can be ugly or handſome, as I pleaſe: go to bed old, and riſe young. I have ſo many Sutes of perſons by me, that I can ſhift 'em when I will.

sp.speaker: Phaed.
sp.p: You are a fool then, to put on your worſt Cloaths, when you come a wooing.

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.p: Go to: Ask no more queſtions; I am for thy turn; for I know thy heart: and ſee all thou haſt about thee.

sp.speaker: Phaed.
sp.p: Then you can ſee my back-ſide too; there's a bargain for you.—

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.p: In thy right pocket:—let me ſee:—three Love Letters from Judge Gripus, written to the bottom, on three ſides; full of fuſtian paſſion, and hearty non-ſence: as alſo in the ſame Pocket, a Letter of thine intended to him; conſiſting of nine lines and a half: ſcrawl'd and falſe ſpell'd, to ſhow thou art a Woman; and full of fraudulence, and equivocations, and ſhoeing-horns of Love to him; to promiſe much, and mean nothing; to ſhow, over and above, that thou art a mere Woman.

sp.speaker: Phaed.
sp.p: Is the Devil in you, to ſee all this? Now, for Heavens ſake, do not look into t'other Pocket.—

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.p: Nay, there's nothing there, but a little godly Prayer-book, and—a bawdy Lampoon, and—

sp.speaker: Phaed.
sp.p: Look no farther, I beſeech you.—

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.p: And a Silver Spoon—

sp.speaker: Phaed.
sp.p: —Ah!

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.p: Which you purloin'd laſt Night from Bromia.

sp.speaker: Phaed.
sp.p: Keep my Counſel, or I am undone for ever.
sp.stage: Holding up her hands to him.

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.p: No: I'll mortifie thee, now I have a handle to thy Iniquity, if thou wilt not love me.—

sp.speaker: Phaed.
sp.p: Well, if you'll promiſe me to be ſecret, I will love you: becauſe indeed I dare doe no other.

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.p: 'Tis a good Girl; I will be ſecret; and further, I will be aſſiſting to thee in thy filching: for thou and I were born under the ſame Planet.

sp.speaker: Phaed.
sp.p: And we ſhall come to the ſame end too, I'm afraid.

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.p: No; no; ſince thou haſt wit enough already to couzin a Judge, thou need'ſt never fear hanging.

sp.speaker: Phaed.
sp.p: And will you make your ſelf a younger man; and be handſome too: and rich? for you that know hearts, muſt needs know, that I ſhall never be conſtant to ſuch an ugly old Soſia.

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.p: Thou ſhalt know more of that another time: in the mean while, here's a caſt of my Office for thee.

div.stage: He ſtamps upon the ground: ſome Dancers come from underground: and others from the ſides of the Stage: A Song, and a fantaſtiok Dance.

lg.head: I.
lg.l: FAir Iris I love, and hourly I dye,

l.hi: But not for a Lip, nor a languiſhing Eye:
She's fickle and falſe, and there we agree;
For I am as falſe, and as fickle as ſhe:
We neither believe what either can ſay;
And, neither believing, we neither betray.

lg.head: II.

l.hi: 'Tis civil to ſwear, and ſay things of courſe;
We mean not the taking for better for worſe.
When preſent, we love; when abſent, agree:

lg.l: I think not of Iris, nor Iris of me:

l.hi: The Legend of Love no Couple can find
So eaſie to part, or ſo equally join'd.

sp.speaker: Phaedra.
sp.p: This Power of yours makes me ſuſpect you for little better than a God; but if you are one, for more certainty, tell me what I am juſt now thinking.

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.p: Why, thou art thinking, let me ſee; for thou art a Woman, and your minds are ſo variable, that it's very hard even for a God to know them. But, to ſatisfie thee, thou art wiſhing, now, for the ſame Power I have exercis'd; that thou mighteſt ſtamp, like me; and have more Singers come up for another Song.

sp.speaker: Phaedra,
sp.p: Gad, I think the Devil's in you. Then I do ſtamp in ſome body's Name, but I know not whoſe; (ſtamps.) Come up, Gentle-folks, from below; and ſing me a Paſtoral Dialogue, where the Woman may have the better of the Man; as we always have in Love matters.

div.stage: [New Singers come up and ſing a Song.

div.head: A Paſtoral Dialogue betwixt Thyrſis and Iris.

lg.head: I.
lg.l: FAir Iris and her Swain▪

l.hi: Were in a ſhady Bow'r;

lg.l: Where Thyrſis long in vain

l.hi: Had ſought the Shepherd's hour:
At length his Hand advancing upon her ſnowy Breaſt;
He ſaid, O kiſs me longer,
And longer yet and longer,
If you will make me Bleſt.

lg.head: II.
lg.l: An eaſie yielding Maid,
By truſting is undone;
Our Sex is oft betray'd,
By granting Love too ſoon.
If you deſire to gain me, your Suff'rings to redreſs;
Prepare to love me longer,
And longer yet, and longer,
Before you ſhall poſſeſs.

lg.head: III.

l.hi: The little Care you ſhow,
Of all my Sorrows paſt;
Makes Death appear too ſlow,
And Life too long to laſt.

lg.l: Fair Iris kiſs me kindly, in pity of my Fate;

l.hi: And kindly ſtill, and kindly,
Before it be too late.

lg.head: IV.
lg.l: You fondly Court your Bliſs,
And no Advances make;
'Tis not for Maids to kiſs,
But 'tis for Men to take.
So you may Kiſs me kindly, and I will not rebell;
And kindly ſtill, and kindly,
But Kiſs me not and tell.

lg.head: V.
A RONDEAU.
lg.l: Thus at the height we love and live,
And fear not to be poor:
We give, and give, and give, and give,
Till we can give no more:
But what to day will take away,
To morrow will reſtore.
Thus at the heighth we love and live,
And fear not to be poor.

sp.speaker: Phaedra.
sp.p: Adieu, I leave you to pay the Muſick: Hope well Mr. Planett; there's a better Heav'n in ſtore for you: I ſay no more, but you can gueſs.

sp.speaker: Mercury,
sp.l: Such Bargain-loves, as I with Phaedra treat,
Are all the Leagues and Friendſhips of the Great:
All ſeek their Ends; and each wou'd other cheat
They onely ſeem to hate, and ſeem to love;
But Int'reſt is the point on which they move.
Their Friends are Foes; and Foes are Friends agen;
And, in their turns, are Knaves, and Honeſt men.
Our Iron Age is grown an Age of Gold:
'Tis who bids moſt; for all Men wou'd be ſold.

div.head: ACT. V.
div.stage: Gripus has the Gobblet in his Hand.

sp.speaker: Phaed.
sp.p: YOU will not be ſo baſe to take it from me?

sp.speaker: Grip.
sp.p: 'Tis my proper Chattel: and I'll ſeize my own, in whatever hands I find it.

sp.speaker: Phaed.
sp.p: You know I onely ſhow'd it you to provoke your generoſity, that you might out-bid your Rival with a better Preſent.

sp.speaker: Grip.
sp.p: My Rival is a Thief: and I'll indite you for a Receiver of Stoln Goods.

sp.speaker: Phaed.
sp.p: Thou Hide-bound Lover▪

sp.speaker: Grip.
sp.p: Thou very mercenary Miſtreſs!

sp.speaker: Phaed.
sp.p: Thou moſt mercenary Magiſtrate!

sp.speaker: Grip.
sp.p: Thou Seller of thy ſelf!

sp.speaker: Phaed.
sp.p: Thou Seller of other People: thou Weather-cock of Government: that when the Wind blows for the Subject, point'ſt to Priviledge; and when it changes for the Soveraign, veers to Prerogative.

sp.speaker: Grip.
sp.p: Will you compound, and take it as my Preſent?

sp.speaker: Phaed.
sp.p: No: but I'll ſend thy Rival to force it from thee.

sp.speaker: Grip.
sp.p: When a Thief is Rival to his Judge, the Hangman will ſoon decide the difference.

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.p: Save your good Lordſhip.

sp.speaker: Grip.
sp.p: From an Impertinent Coxcomb: I am out of humour, and am in haſt: leave me.

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.p: 'Tis my duty to attend on your Lordſhip, and to eaſe you of that undecent Burden.

sp.speaker: Grip.
sp.p: Gold was never any Burden, to one of my Profeſſion.

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.p: By your Lordſhip's permiſſion, Phaedra has ſent me to take it from you.

sp.speaker: Grip.
sp.p: What, by Violence?

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.p: No; but by your Honour's permiſſion, I am to reſtore it to her, and perſwade your Lordſhip, to renounce your Pretenſions to her.

sp.speaker: Grip.
sp.p: Tell her flatly, I will neither do one, nor t'other.

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.p: O my good Lord, I dare paſs my word for your free conſent to both.—Will your Honour be pleas'd to take your choice of one of theſe?

sp.speaker: Grip.
sp.p: Why theſe are Swords: what have I to do with them?

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.p: Onely to take your choice of one of them; which your Lordſhip pleaſes; and leave the other to your moſt Obedient Servant.

sp.speaker: Grip.
sp.p: What, one of theſe ungodly Weapons? take notice, I'll lay you by the heels, Sirrah: this has the appearance of an unlawfull bloody challenge.

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.p: You Magiſtrates are pleas'd to call it ſo, my Lord; but with us Swordmen, 'tis an honourable Invitation to the cutting of one anothers Throats.

sp.speaker: Grip.
sp.p: Be anſwer'd; I have no Throat to cut. The Law ſhall decide our Controverſie.

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.p: By your permiſſion, my Lord; it muſt be diſpatch'd, this way.

sp.speaker: Grip.
sp.p: I'll ſee thee hang'd before I give thee any ſuch permiſſion, to diſpatch me into another World.

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.p: At the leaſt, my Lord, you have no occaſion to complain of my want of reſpect to you: you will neither reſtore the Gobblet, nor renounce Phaedra: I offer you the Combat; you refuſe it: all this is done in the forms of honour: it follows, that I am to affront, cudgel you, or kick you, at my own arbitrement; and I ſuppoſe, you are too honourable not to approve of my proceeding.

sp.speaker: Grip.
sp.p: Here's a new ſort of Proceſs, that was never heard of in any of our Courts.

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.p: This, my good Lord, is Law in Short-hand, without your long Preambles, and tedious Repetitions, that ſignifie nothing, but to ſqueeze the Subject: therefore, with your Lordſhip's favour, I begin.

sp.speaker: Grip.
sp.p: What's this for?

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.p: To give you an occaſion of returning me a box o'th' Ear: that ſo, all things may proceed methodically.

sp.speaker: Grip.
sp.p: I put in no anſwer, but ſuffer a Non-ſuit.

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.p: No, my Lord; for the Coſts and Charges are to be paid: will you pleaſe to reſtore the Cup?

sp.speaker: Grip.
sp.p: I have told thee, no.

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.p: Then from your Chin, I muſt aſcend to your Lordſhip's Ears.

sp.speaker: Grip.
sp.p: Oh, oh. Oh, oh.—Wilt thou never-leave lugging me by the Ears?

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.p: Not till your Lordſhip will be pleas'd to hear reaſon.

sp.speaker: Grip.
sp.p: Take the Cup; and the Devil give thee joy on't.

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.p: And your Lordſhip will farther be graciouſly pleas'd, to releaſe all claims, titles, and actions whatſoever to Phaedra: You muſt give me leave to add one ſmall memento, for that too.

sp.speaker: Grip.
sp.p: I renounce her, I releaſe her.

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.p: Phaedra; My Lord has been pleas'd to be very gracious; without puſhing matters to extremity.

sp.speaker: Phaed.
sp.p: I over-heard it all: But give me Livery and Seiſin of the Gobblet, in the firſt place.

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.p: There's an Act of Oblivion ſhou'd be paſs'd too.

sp.speaker: Phaed.
sp.p: Let him begin to remember quarrels, when he dares; now I have him under my Girdle, I'll cap Verſes with him to the end of the Chapter.

sp.speaker: Amph.
sp.p: At the laſt I have got poſſeſſion without your Lordſhip's Warrant; Phaedra, tell Alcmena I am here.

sp.speaker: Phaed.
sp.p: I'll carry no ſuch lying Meſſage: you are not here, and you cannot be here: for, to my knowledge, you are above with my Lady, in the Chamber!

sp.speaker: Amph.
sp.p: All of a piece, and all Witchcraft! Anſwer me preciſely; do'ſt thou not know me for Amphitryon?

sp.speaker: Phaed.
sp.p: Anſwer me firſt: did you give me a Diamond, and a Purſe of Gold?

sp.speaker: Amph.
sp.p: Thou know'ſt I did not.

sp.speaker: Phaed.
sp.p: Then, by the ſame token, I know you are not the true Amphitryon: if you are he, I am ſure I left you in bed with your own Wife: now you had beſt ſtretch out a leg; and feel about for a fair Lady.

sp.speaker: Amph.
sp.p: I'll undo this Enchantment with my Sword; and kill the Sorcerer: Come up, Gentlemen, and follow me.

sp.speaker: Phaed.
sp.p: I'll ſave you the labour; and call him down to confront you; if you dare attend him.

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.p: Now the Spell is ended, and Jupiter can enchant no more; or elſe Amphitryon had not enter'd ſo eaſily. [Gripus is ſtealing off.] —Whither now, Gripus? I have buſineſs for you: if you offer to ſtir, you know what follows.

div.stage: Enter Jupiter, follow'd by Tranio and Polydas.

sp.speaker: Jupit.
sp.l: Who dares to play the Maſter in my Houſe?
What noiſe is this, that calls me from above,
Invades my ſoft receſs, and privacy,
And, like a Tyde, breaks in upon my Love?

sp.speaker: Amph.
sp.l: O Heav'ns, what's this I ſee?

sp.speaker: Tran.
sp.l: What Prodigy!

sp.speaker: Polyd.
sp.l: How, two Amphitryons!

sp.speaker: Grip.
sp.l: I have beheld th' appearance of two Suns;
But ſtill the falſe, was dimmer than the true;
Here, both ſhine out alike.

sp.speaker: Amph.
sp.l: This is a ſight, that like the Gorgon's head,
Runs through my limbs, and ſtiffens me to Stone.
I need no more inquire into my fate:
For what I ſee, reſolves my doubts too plain.

sp.speaker: Tran.
sp.l: Two drops of water, cannot be more like.

sp.speaker: Polyd.
sp.l: They are two very ſame's.

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.p: Our Jupiter is a great Comedian; he counterfeits moſt admirably: ſure his Prieſts have coppy'd their Hypocriſie from their Maſter.

sp.speaker: Amph.
sp.l: Now, I am gather'd back into my ſelf,
My Heart beats high, and puſhes out the Blood
To give me juſt revenge on this Impoſtour.
If you are brave, aſſiſt me—not one ſtirs:
What are all brib'd to take th' Enchanters part?
'Tis true, the work is mine; and thus.—
sp.stage: [Going to ruſh upon Jupiter; and is held by Tranio and Polydas.]

sp.speaker: Polyd.
sp.l: It muſt not be.

sp.speaker: Jupit.
sp.l: Give him his way: I dare the Madman's worſt:
But ſtill take notice, that it looks not like
The true Amphitryon, to fly out, at firſt
To brutal force: it ſhows he doubts his Cauſe,
Who dares not truſt his reaſon to defend it.

sp.speaker: Amph.
sp.l: Thou baſe Uſurper of my Name, and Bed;
No leſs than thy Hearts-blood can waſh away
Th' affronts I have ſuſtain'd.

sp.speaker: Tranio.
sp.l: We muſt not ſuffer
So ſtrange a Duel as Amphitryon
To fight againſt himſelf.

sp.speaker: Polyd.
sp.l: Nor think we wrong you, when we hold your hands:
We know our duty to our General:
We know the tyes of Friendſhip to our Friend:
But who that Friend, or who that Gen'ral is,
Without more certain proofs betwixt you two,
Is hard to be diſtinguiſh'd, by our reaſon:
Impoſſible by ſight.

sp.speaker: Amph.
sp.l: I know it; and have ſatisfy'd my ſelf:
I am the true Amphitryon.

sp.speaker: Jupit.
sp.l: See again.
He ſhuns the certain proofs; and dares not ſtand
Impartial Judgment, and award of right.
But ſince Alcmena's honour is concern'd,
Whom, more than Heav'n, and all the World, I love;
This I propoſe, as equal to us both.
Tranio, and Polydas, be you Aſſiſtants,
The Guards be ready to ſecure th' Impoſtour,
When once ſo prov'd, for publick puniſhment;
And Gripus, be thou Umpire of the Cauſe.

sp.speaker: Amph.
sp.l: I am content: let him proceed to Examination.

sp.speaker: Grip.
sp.l: On whoſe ſide wou'd you pleaſe that I ſhou'd give the Sentence?

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.p:
Follow thy Conſcience for once; but not to make a Cuſtom of it neither; nor to leave an evil precedent of Uprightneſs to future
Judges. (Aſide) 'Tis a good thing to have a Magiſtrate under Correction: Your old fornicating Judge, dare never give Sentence againſt him that knows his haunts.

sp.speaker: Polyd.
sp.p: Your Lordſhip knows I was Maſter of Amphitryon's Ship; and deſire to know of him, what paſs'd in private betwixt us two, at his Landing, when he was juſt ready to engage the Enemy?

sp.speaker: Grip.
sp.p: Let the true Amphitryon anſwer firſt.—

sp.speaker: Jupit. & Amph.
sp.p: My Lord I told him.—

sp.speaker: Grip.
sp.p: Peace both of you:—'Tis a plain Caſe they are both true; for they both ſpeak together: but for more certainty, let the falſe Amphitryon▪ ſpeak firſt.

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.p: Now they are both ſilent.—

sp.speaker: Grip.
sp.p: Then it's as plain on t'other ſide, that they are both falſe Amphitryons.

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.p: Which Amphitryon ſhall ſpeak firſt?

sp.speaker: Grip.
sp.p: Let the Cholerick Amphitryon ſpeak; and let the peaceable hold his peace.

sp.speaker: Amph.
sp.p: You may remember that I whiſper'd you, not to part from the Stern, one ſingle Moment.

sp.speaker: Polyd.
sp.p: You did ſo.

sp.speaker: Grip.
sp.p: No more words then; I proceed to Sentence.

sp.speaker: Jupit.
sp.p: 'Twas I that whiſper'd him; and he may remember I gave him this reaſon for it; That if our Men were beaten, I might ſecure my own retreat.

sp.speaker: Polyd.
sp.p: You did ſo.

sp.speaker: Grip.
sp.p: Now again he's as true as t'other.

sp.speaker: Tranio.
sp.p: You know I was Pay-maſter: What directions did you give me the night before the Battle?

sp.speaker: Grip.
sp.p: To which of the You's art thou ſpeaking?

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.p: It ſhou'd be a double U: but they have no ſuch letter in their Tongue.

sp.speaker: Amph.
sp.p: I order'd you to take particular care of the great Bag.

sp.speaker: Grip.
sp.p: Why this is demonſtration.

sp.speaker: Jupit.
sp.p: The Bag that I recommended to you, was of Tygers skin; and mark'd Beta.

sp.speaker: Grip.
sp.p: In ſadneſs I think they are both Jugglers: Here's nothing, and here's nothing: and then hiccius doccius, and they are both here again.

sp.speaker: Tran.
sp.p: You peaceable Amphitryon, what Money was there in that Bag?

sp.speaker: Jupit.
sp.p: The ſumm in groſs, amounted juſt to fifty Attick Talents.

sp.speaker: Tran▪
sp.p: To a farthing?

sp.speaker: Grip.
sp.p: Paugh: obvious, obvious.

sp.speaker: Amph.
sp.p: Two thouſand pieces of Gold were ty'd up in a Handkerchief by themſelves.

sp.speaker: Tran.
sp.p: I remember it.

sp.speaker: Grip.
sp.p: Then 'tis dubious again.

sp.speaker: Jupit.
sp.p: But the reſt was not all Silver; for there were juſt four thouſand Braſs half-pence.

sp.speaker: Grip.
sp.p: Being but Braſs, the proof is inconſiderable: if they had been Silver, it had gone on your ſide.

sp.speaker: Amph.
sp.p: Death and Hell, you will not perſwade me, that I did not kill Pterelas?

sp.speaker: Jupit.
sp.p: Nor you me, that I did not enjoy Alcmena?

sp.speaker: Amph.
sp.l: That laſt was poyſon to me.—
Yet there's one proof thou canſt not counterfeit:
In killing Pterelas, I had a Wound
Full in the brawny part of my right Arme:
Where ſtill the Scar remains: now bluſh, Impoſtour;
For this thou canſt not ſhow.
sp.stage: [Bares his Arme; and ſhows the Scar, which they all look on.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.p: This is the true Amphitryon.

sp.speaker: Jupit.
sp.p: May your Lordſhip pleaſe.—

sp.speaker: Grip.
sp.p: No, Sirrah, it does not pleaſe me: hold your tongue, I charge you; for the Caſe is manifeſt.

sp.speaker: Jupit.
sp.p: By your favour then, this ſhall ſpeak for me.
sp.stage: Bares his Arme; and ſhows it.

sp.speaker: Tran.
sp.p: 'Tis juſt in the ſame Muſcle.

sp.speaker: Polyd.
sp.p: Of the ſame length and breadth; and the Scar of the ſame blewiſh colour.

sp.speaker: Grip.
sp.p: Did not I charge you not to ſpeak? 'twas plain enough before: and now you have puzzled it again.

sp.speaker: Amph.
sp.p: Good Gods, how can this be!

sp.speaker: Grip.
sp.p: For certain there was but one Pterelas; and he muſt have been in the Plot againſt himſelf too: for he was kill'd firſt by one of them; and then riſe again out of reſpect to t'other Amphitryon, to be kill'd twice over.

sp.speaker: Alcm.
sp.l: No more of this; it ſounds impoſſible
That two ſhou'd be ſo like, no difference found.

sp.speaker: Phaed.
sp.p: You'll find it true.

sp.speaker: Alcm.
sp.l: Then where's Alcmena's honour and her fame?
Farewell my needleſs fear; it cannot be:
This is a Caſe too nice for vulgar ſight:
But let me come; my Heart will guide my Eyes
To point, and tremble to its proper choice.
There neither was, nor is, but one Amphitryon;
And I am onely his.—
sp.stage: [Goes to take him by the Hand.

sp.speaker: Amph.
sp.p: Away, Adultreſs!

sp.speaker: Jupit.
sp.l: My gentle Love: my Treaſure and my Joy;
Follow no more, that falſe and fooliſh Fire,
That wou'd miſlead thy Fame to ſure deſtruction!
Look on thy better Husband, and thy friend,
Who will not leave thee lyable to ſcorn,
But vindicate thy honour from that Wretch
Who wou'd by baſe aſperſions blot thy vertue.

sp.speaker: Alcm.
sp.stage: going to him, who embraces her.
sp.l: I was indeed miſtaken; thou art he!
Thy Words, thy Thoughts, thy Soul is all Amphitryon.
Th' Impoſtour has thy Features, not thy Mind;
The Face might have deceiv'd me in my choice;
Thy kindneſs is a Guide that cannot err.

sp.speaker: Amph.
sp.l: What in my preſence to prefer the Villain!
O execrable cheat! I break the truce;
And will no more attend your vain deciſions;
To this—and to the Gods I'll truſt my Cauſe.
sp.stage: [Is ruſhing upon Jupiter, and is held again.

sp.speaker: Jupit.
sp.l: Poor Man; how I contemn thoſe idle threats!
Were I diſpos'd, thou might'ſt as ſafely meet
The Thunder lanch'd from the red arme of Jove:)
(Nor Jove need bluſh to be Alcmena's Champion.)
But in the face of Thebes, ſhe ſhall be clear'd:
And what I am, and what thou art, be known.
Attend, and I will bring convincing proof.

sp.speaker: Amph.
sp.l: Thou wou'dſt elude my Juſtice, and eſcape;
But I will follow thee, through Earth, and Seas;
Nor Hell ſhall hide thee, from my juſt revenge.

sp.speaker: Jupit.
sp.l: I'll ſpare thy pains: it ſhall be quickly ſeen,
Bewixt us two, who ſeeks, and who avoids.—
Come in my Friends: and thou who ſeem'ſt Amphitryon;
That all who are in doubt, may know the true.

div.stage: Jupiter re-enters the Houſe: with him Amphitryon, Alcmena, Polydas, Tranio, and Guards.

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.stage: to Grip. and Brom. who are following.
sp.l: Thou Gripus, and you Bromia; ſtay with Phaedra:
Let their affairs alone, and mind we ours:
Amphitryon's Rival ſhall appear a God:
But know before-hand, I am Mercury;
Who want not Heav'n, while Phaedra is on Earth.

sp.speaker: Brom.
sp.p: But, and't pleaſe your Lordſhip, is my fellow Phaedra to be exalted into the Heav'ns, and made a Star?

sp.speaker: Phaed.
sp.p: When that comes to paſs, if you look up a-nights, I ſhall remember old kindneſs, and vouchſafe to twinkle on you.

div.stage: Enter Soſia, peeping about him: and ſeeing Mercury, is ſtarting back.

sp.speaker: Soſia.
sp.p: Here he is again; and there's no paſſing by him into the Houſe, unleſs I were a Spright, to glide in through the Key-hole.—I am to be a Vagabond I find.

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.p: Soſia, come back.

sp.speaker: Soſia.
sp.p: No I thank you; you may whiſtle me long enough; a beaten Dog has always the wit to avoid his Maſter.

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.p: I permit thee to be Soſia again.

sp.speaker: Soſia.
sp.p: 'Tis an unfortunate Name, and I abandon it: he that has an itch to be beaten, let him take it up for Soſia;—What have I ſaid now! I mean for me; for I neither am nor will be Soſia.

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.p: But thou may'ſt be ſo in ſafety: for I have acknowledg'd my ſelf to be God Mercury.

sp.speaker: Soſia.
sp.p: You may be a God, for ought I know; but the Devil take me if ever I Worſhip you; for an unmercifull Deity, as you are

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.p: You ought to take it for an honour to be drubb'd by the hand of a Divinity.

sp.speaker: Soſia.
sp.p: I am your moſt humble Servant, good Mr. God; but by the ſaith of a Mortal, I cou'd well have ſpar'd the honour that you did me. But how ſhall I be ſure that you will never aſſume my ſhape again?

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.p: Becauſe I am weary of wearing ſo villanous an outſide.

sp.speaker: Soſia.
sp.p: Well, well; as villanous as it is, here's old Bromia will be contented with it.

sp.speaker: Brom.
sp.p: Yes, now I am ſure that I may chaſtiſe you ſafely: and that there's no God, lurking under your appearance.

sp.speaker: Soſia.
sp.p: Ay; but you had beſt take heed how you attempt it: for as Mercury has turn'd himſelf into me, ſo I may take the toy into my head, to turn my ſelf into Mercury, that I may ſwinge you off, condignly.

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.p: In the mean time, be all my Witneſſes, that I take Phaedra for my Wife of the left hand; that is, in the nature of a lawfull Concubine.

sp.speaker: Phaed.
sp.p: You ſhall pardon me for believing you, for all you are a God: for you have a terrible ill name below: and I am affraid you'll get a Footman, inſtead of a Prieſt, to Marry us.

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.p: But here's Gripus ſhall draw up Articles betwixt us.

sp.speaker: Phaed.
sp.p: But he's damnably u'sd to falſe Conveyancing:—Well be it ſo: for my Counſel ſhall over-look 'em before I Sign: Come on, Gripus; that I may have him under black and white
sp.stage: [Here Gripus gets ready Pen, Ink, and Paper.

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.p: With all my heart; that I may have thee under black and white hereafter.

sp.speaker: Phaed.
sp.p: Begin, begin; Heads of Articles to be made, &c. betwixt Mercury, God of Thieves—

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.p: And Phaedra, Queen of Gypſies.—Imprimis, I promiſe to buy and ſettle upon her an Eſtate, containing Nine thouſand Acres of Land, in any part of Boeotia, to her own liking.

sp.speaker: Phaed.
sp.p: Provided always, that no part of the ſaid Nine thouſand Acres ſhall be upon, or adjoyning to Mount Parnaſſus: for I will not be fobb'd off with a Poetical Eſtate.

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.p: Memorandum, that ſhe be always conſtant to me; and admit no other Lover.

sp.speaker: Phaed.
sp.p: Memorandum, unleſs it be a Lover that offers more: and that the Conſtancy ſhall not exceed the Settlement.

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.p: Item, that ſhe ſhall keep no Male Servants in her houſe: Item, no Rival Lap Dog for a Bedfellow: Item, that ſhe ſhall never pray to any of the Gods.

sp.speaker: Phaed.
sp.p: What, wou'd you have me an Atheiſt?

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.p: No Devotion to any He-Deity, good Phaedra.

sp.speaker: Brom.
sp.p: Here's no proviſion made for Children yet.

sp.speaker: Phaed.
sp.p: Well remember'd, Bromia: I bargain that my Eldeſt Son ſhall be a Hero, and my Eldeſt Daughter a King's Miſtreſs.

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.p: That is to ſay, a Blockhead, and a Harlot, Phaedra.

sp.speaker: Phaed.
sp.p: That's true; but who dares call 'em ſo? Then for the Younger Children:—but now I think on't, we'll have no more, but Maſs and Miſs; for the reſt wou'd be but chargeable, and a burden to the Nation.

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.p: Yes, yes; the Second ſhall be a Falſe Prophet: he ſhall have Wit enough to ſet up a New Religion: and too much Wit to dye a Martyr for it.

sp.speaker: Phaed.
sp.p: O what had I forgot? there's Pin-money, and Ali-money, and Seperate maintenance, and a thouſand things more to be conſider'd; that are all to be tack'd to this Act of Settlement.

sp.speaker: Soſia.
sp.p: I am a fool, I muſt confeſs; but yet I can ſee as far into a Mill-ſtone as the beſt of you: I have obſerv'd that you Women-Wits are commonly ſo quick upon the ſcent, that you often over-run it: Now I wou'd ask of Madam Phaedra, that in caſe Mr. Heaven there, ſhou'd be pleas'd to break theſe Articles, in what Court of Judicature ſhe intends to ſue him?

sp.speaker: Phaed.
sp.p: The fool has hit upon't:—Gods, and great Men, are never to be ſued; for they can always plead priviledge of Peerage: and therefore for once, Mounſieur, I'll take your word; for as long as you love me you'll be ſure to keep it: and in the mean time I ſhall be gaining experience how to manage ſome rich Cully; for no Woman ever made her Fortune by a Wit.

div.stage: It Thunders; and the Company within doors: Amphitryon, Alcmena, Polydas, and Tranio, all come running out, and joyn with the reſt, who were on the Theatre before.

sp.speaker: Amph.
sp.l: Sure 'tis ſome God: he vaniſh'd from our ſight,
And told, us we ſhou'd ſee him ſoon return▪

sp.speaker: Alcm.
sp.l: I know not what to hope, nor what to fear.
A ſimple Errour, is a real Crime;
And unconſenting Innocence is loſt.

div.stage: A ſecond Peal of Thunder. After which, Jupiter appears in a Machine.

sp.speaker: Jupit.
sp.l: Look up, Amphitryon, and behold above,
Th' Impoſtour God, the Rival of thy Love:
In thy own ſhape, ſee Jupiter appear,
And let that ſight, ſecure thy jealous fear
Diſgrace, and Infamy, are turn'd to boaſt:
No Fame, in Jove's Concurrence can be loſt:
What he enjoys, he ſanctifies from Vice;
And by partaking, ſtamps into a price.
'Tis I, who ought to murmur at my Fate;
Forc'd by my Love, my Godhead to tranſlate;
When on no other terms I cou'd poſſeſs,
But by thy form, thy features, and thy dreſs;
To thee were giv'n, the Bleſſings that I ſought,
Which elſe, not all the bribes of Heav'n had bought.
Then take into thy Armes thy envy'd Love;
And, in his own deſpight, triumph o'er Jove.

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.p: Amphitryon and Alcmena, both ſtand mute, and know not how to take it.

sp.speaker: Soſia.
sp.p: Our Soveraign Lord Jupiter is a ſly Companion; he knows how to gild a bitter Pill.

sp.speaker: Jupit.
sp.l: From this auſpicious Night, ſhall riſe an Heir,
Great, like his Sire, and like his Mother, fair:
Wrongs to redreſs, and Tyrants to diſſeize;
Born for a World, that wants a Hercules.
Monſters, and Monſter-men he ſhall ingage,
And toil, and ſtruggle, through an Impious Age
Peace to his Labours, ſhall at length ſucceed,
And murm'ring Men, unwilling to be freed,
Shall be compell'd to Happineſs, by need.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.p: We all Congratulate Amphitryon.

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.p: Keep your Congratulations to your ſelves, Gentlemen: 'Tis a nice point, let me tell you that; and the leſs that is ſaid of it, the better. Upon the whole matter, if Amphitryon takes the favour of Jupiter in patience, as from a God, he's a good Heathen.

sp.speaker: Soſia.
sp.p: I muſt take a little extraordinary pains to night, that my Spouſe may come even with her Lady, and produce a Squire to attend on young Hercules, when he goes out to ſeek Adventures; that when his Maſter kills a Man, he may ſtand ready to pick his Pockets; and piouſly relieve his Aged Parents. Ah, Bromia, Bromia; if thou hadſt been as handſome and as young as Phaedra; I ſay no more, but ſome-body might have made his Fortunes as well as his Maſter, and never the worſe Man neither.
sp.l: For, let the wicked World ſay what they pleaſe,
The fair Wife makes her Husband live at eaſe:
The Lover keeps him too; and but receives,
Like Jove, the remnants that Amphitryon leaves:
'Tis true, the Lady has enough in ſtore,
To ſatisfie thoſe two, and eke, two more:
In fine, the Man, who weighs the matter fully,
Wou'd rather be the Cuckold, than the Cully.

lg.l: I'M thinking, (and it almoſt makes me mad,)
How ſweet a time, thoſe Heathen Ladies had.
Idolatry, was ev'n their Gods own trade;
They Worſhipt the ſine Creatures they had made.
Cupid, was chief of all the Deities;
And Love was all the faſhion, in the Skies.
When the ſweet Nymph, held up the Lilly hand,
Jove, was her humble Servant, at Command.
The Treaſury of Heav'n was ne're ſo bare,
But ſtill there was a Penſion for the Fair.
In all his Reign, Adultry was no Sin;
For Jove, the good Example did begin.
Mark, too when he uſurp'd the Husband's name,
How civilly he ſav'd the Ladies fame.
The ſecret Joys of Love, he wiſely hid;
But you, Sirs, boaſt of more, than e'er you did.
You teize your Cuckolds; to their face torment 'em;
But Jove gave his, new Honours to content 'em.
And, in the kind remembrance of the Fair,
On each exalted Son, beſtow'd a Star.
For thoſe good deeds, as by the date appears,
His Godſhip, flouriſh'd full Two thouſand Years.
